They were real pioneers I think in presenting
childhood experience to the world, so if you

41.text:
look at earlier novels, say Jane Austen, for
example, children aren't very important to

46.text:
that at all, but suddenly in the mid-19th
century, there is suddenly a whole string

51.text:
of important novels with children absolutely
at their centre. Oliver Twist is one, Wuthering

57.text:
Heights is another - you think how important
the early childhood years of Heathcliff and

62.text:
Cathy are. David Copperfield is another, then
Great Expectations, but really Jane Eyre has

67.text:
the most important role of all of those because
it's really the first time you get someone

74.text:
narrating, not from, not by a child, but from
a child's point of view or from a child's

80.text:
perspective and bringing you so close to what
it feels like to be a child and she immediately

88.text:
influences, say, Dickens, who then goes to
write David Copperfield, so it's enormously

93.text:
influential. It's like a whole terrain of
human experience that comes through into the

100.text:
novel through Jane Eyre, so earlier romantic
writers, like Wordsworth or Blake that bring

105.text:
poetry thinking about the child and valuing
the child's experience, but Jane Eyre has

111.text:
a unique importance in bringing that to the
novel.

118.text:
Now their own childhood was in some ways,
unique, like no other childhood really and

130.text:
also very unhappy because their mother dies
when they were very young, their elder siblings

135.text:
die and they then get sent to this terrible
school, which is the basis for Jane's account

144.text:
of her childhood in Jane Eyre and it must
have been a very difficult time for both of

151.text:
them and there was the threat of death was
imminent there, but also the whole understanding

158.text:
of childhood, of Carus Wilson who was the
head teacher, was so different from those

165.text:
romantic ideas, of the child being someone
who should be fostered and helped to grow,

172.text:
so that Evangelical Christians in this period
felt that children were intrinsically sinful

179.text:
and that it was important to break their will
early on and so Carus Wilson writes, for example,

185.text:
a set of little stories, Child's First Tales
and they are very scary and they're meant

191.text:
to be scary. They are about children who are
hanged, or sent to jail, or who are punished

196.text:
and there is a constant emphasis on suffering
and on early death.

202.text:
This is actually a book would be in use at
school at that time. It is written by Reverend

208.text:
Carus Wilson and it is dated 1836 and they
are full of quite grim stories, intended to

216.text:
frighten children into good behaviour, so
we get terrible accounts of the punishments

224.text:
that were inflicted on naughty children and
these are illustrated like these gruesome

230.text:
little woodcuts and children who are struck
down dead for telling a lie. Punishments for

237.text:
things that we would consider quite, well,
not really terribly serious nowadays, so the

244.text:
book ends with quite a distressing story called
‘Mother dead’, with an illustration and

253.text:
it's two poor girls whose mother has died
and the big girl takes the sheet off the face

258.text:
to have one more look and the least girl cries
at the foot of the bed and she can't look

262.text:
up. They have lost their best friend and the
story goes on to say, ‘my dear child, have

264.text:
you a mother? Thank God that he spares her
to you. These poor girls did not know how

273.text:
dear their mother was till she was gone. They
may have been bad girls, they may have made

281.text:
their poor mother’s heart ache and if so,
they would say “Oh if she would but come

285.text:
again, I think I'd vex her so no more." Mind
my dear child who reads this tale, do not

292.text:
vex your mother. If God takes her from you,
it may be in his wrath.’ So this is the

298.text:
kind of distressing story that was being doled
out to these very young children. Quite, quite

304.text:
disturbing stuff on whatever the situation
at Cowan Bridge and whether it really was

311.text:
the basis for Lowood, I think these books
tell you really all you need to know.

316.text:
Their father, Patrick Brontë, goes away and
comes back with some toy soldiers for them

331.text:
and the children are very very excited by
this and they write little accounts of them

335.text:
and then those 12 soldiers, they give names
to them and start to create biographies for

341.text:
them. They then start to create a world in
which they live. They create little magazines

346.text:
about them called The Twelves they're called
and from these toy soldiers they create, they

351.text:
populate a world really. They create a whole
country in Africa and then it shows the way

359.text:
that play can mutates or changes into fiction
for them and that the two are so closely bound

368.text:
together and that I think is one of the reasons
why they're such uniquely creative authors,

375.text:
why they can make such a huge difference to
what the novel is, because they seem to have

379.text:
this, this kind of tap root back into very
early childhood experiences without inhibition,

385.text:
so they can tap all those quite primal emotions
and feelings and fantasies and at the same

392.text:
time, give them adult control and discipline
and shape.
